prompt_text:
Create a comprehensive, role-tailored Volunteer Onboarding Checklist for [ORGANIZATION NAME]’s [PROGRAM NAME] that balances warmth with compliance and works for small teams with limited admin time.

CUSTOMIZATION FIELDS (fill in before generating)
- Organization: [ORGANIZATION NAME]
- Program: [PROGRAM NAME]
- Volunteer roles: [VOLUNTEER ROLES, e.g., “tutors, event support, admin”]
- Role risk level: [LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH; e.g., child-facing, transportation]
- Background check type: [BACKGROUND CHECK TYPE, e.g., “state criminal, FBI fingerprint, MVR”]
- Jurisdiction: [JURISDICTION, e.g., “CA, Ontario”]
- Point of contact (POC): [POINT OF CONTACT NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]
- Secondary/after-hours contact: [NAME, EMAIL, PHONE] (optional)
- Tracking system: [Airtable/Google Sheets/Asana/Excel/other]
- Languages available: [LANGUAGES] (optional)
- Tone: [WARM / FORMAL / CASUAL]
- Signature title: [TITLE, e.g., “Volunteer Coordinator”]
- Today’s date: [DATE]

CONTENT REQUIREMENTS
Timeline structure (group all steps under these phases)
1) Pre-Start (before first shift)
2) Day 1 (first shift/orientation)
3) Week 1 (first 7 days)
4) Month 1 (first 30 days)

For each checklist item include
- Step name (start with a verb)
- Why it matters (1 sentence)
- Owner (Staff or Volunteer)
- Due date/timing (specific: “before first shift,” “within 3 business days”)
- Link/Location (URL, folder, or contact)
- Checkbox (☐)
- Plus columns for Status and Notes (for tracking)

Example checklist row
Complete background check | Protects clients and meets [JURISDICTION] rules | Staff | Within 5 business days of conditional offer | HR: /Volunteer/BackgroundChecks | ☐

Compliance essentials (include all; align to [JURISDICTION])
- [BACKGROUND CHECK TYPE] completed and cleared (add MVR for driving, sex offender registry where required)
- Signed liability waiver
- Confidentiality/privacy agreement (HIPAA/PHI/PII if applicable)
- Photo/media consent (opt-in/opt-out)
- Emergency contact info collected
- Safety procedures review (exits, PPE, first aid, emergencies)
- Incident reporting process
- Code of conduct acknowledgment
- Any [JURISDICTION]-specific items (e.g., mandated reporter training, TB test, food handler card)

Role variations and safeguards
- Role-specific tasks/training for [VOLUNTEER ROLES]
- HIGH risk (child/vulnerable/transport): enhanced checks, boundaries training, supervised shadowing (2–4 shifts), two-adult rule, driving verification (license/insurance), tighter incident escalation
- MEDIUM risk: standard checks, buddy system, first two shifts supervised
- LOW risk: basic orientation, data privacy mini-training (if handling info)

Orientation and culture
- Mission, values, and who we serve
- Program goals and impact
- Role scope and boundaries (what to do/not do)
- DEI expectations and inclusive language
- Current health/safety protocols (COVID-19 or other)
- Data handling and device/security basics
- Facilities tour or virtual equivalent; access/badges
- First assignment checklist and role tools overview

Relationship-building
- Welcome script (60–90 words) from program lead that thanks the volunteer, sets expectations, and invites questions
- Introductions to key staff and experienced volunteers
- Shadowing plan (who to observe, how many shifts)
- Mentor/buddy assignment (name and contact)
- First assignment checklist (step-by-step for the first shift)

Support resources
- FAQs (exactly 5):
  1) Time commitment and scheduling
  2) What to wear/bring
  3) Parking/transport/facility access
  4) Cancellation/absence policy
  5) Who to contact for questions or problems
- Key contacts block:
  - Primary: [POINT OF CONTACT NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]
  - Secondary/after-hours contact
  - Emergency number/location procedures
- Simple welcome kit list (e.g., name tag, handbook, t-shirt, badge, parking info, tool links)

Accessibility and inclusion
- Ask: “Do you need any accommodations or have access needs (mobility, sensory, schedule, communication, dietary, prayer space)?” Provide space to answer and a confidential contact.
- Language access: “This is available in [LANGUAGES] on request.”
- Make printable version clear and accessible (plain fonts, high contrast, large-print option).

Tracking and system integration
- Add Status (Not Started/In Progress/Complete) and Notes columns.
- Include setup note: “Recommended for use in [SYSTEM]. Sort/filter by Phase, Owner, or Status. Template available from [POC].”

FORMAT SPECIFICATIONS (deliver both)
Format A: Table-Style Checklist
- Columns: Phase | Step | Why It Matters | Owner | Due Date | Link/Location | Status | Notes | ☐
- Sortable/filterable, suitable for [SYSTEM]
- Include 15–25 total rows across phases (keep concise; link out for detail)

Format B: Printable Checklist
- Brief welcome blurb at top (2–3 sentences)
- Space for Volunteer Name, Start Date, Mentor/Buddy, and POC
- Group by phase with clear subheads and checkboxes
- Print-friendly (B/W, standard margins)

STYLE AND QUALITY STANDARDS
- Tone: Apply [TONE]. Be appreciative, clear, and firm on safety.
- Reading level: 6th–8th grade; plain language; no jargon or buzzwords.
- Actionable steps (start with verbs).
- Specific timing (avoid “ASAP”).
- Each “why it matters” ties to mission, safety, or compliance.
- A new coordinator can run this without extra training.
- Total length: 800–1,200 words (checklist items, welcome script, FAQs, resources combined).

WHAT TO AVOID
- Vague timing, passive voice, and long policy blocks in-line (link instead).
- Clichés and assumptions about prior experience.

SIGNATURE AND VERSION CONTROL
End the output with:
- Author line: “[TITLE], [ORGANIZATION NAME]”
- Last updated: [DATE]
- Questions? Contact [POINT OF CONTACT NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]

USE CASES AND UPDATE TRIGGERS
- Use for onboarding, training new coordinators, and compliance audits for [JURISDICTION].
- Update when laws change, roles/risk shift, or feedback shows gaps.

Here are the comprehensive, role-tailored Volunteer Onboarding Checklists for Project Uplift's Homework Helpers program, balancing warmth with compliance for small teams.

**Customization Fields Used:**

*   **Organization:** Project Uplift
*   **Program:** Homework Helpers
*   **Volunteer roles:** Tutors
*   **Role risk level:** MEDIUM (direct interaction with vulnerable population, but supervised)
*   **Background check type:** Washington State Patrol (WATCH) criminal check, Sex Offender Registry
*   **Jurisdiction:** WA (Washington State)
*   **Point of contact (POC):** Maria Lopez, volunteers@projectuplift.org, (509) 555-0148
*   **Secondary/after-hours contact:** David Chen, david.chen@projectuplift.org, (509) 555-0149 (optional)
*   **Tracking system:** Google Sheets
*   **Languages available:** Spanish, Vietnamese
*   **Tone:** WARM
*   **Signature title:** Volunteer Coordinator
*   **Today's date:** October 26, 2023

---

### Format A: Table-Style Checklist (for Google Sheets)

**Setup Note:** Recommended for use in Google Sheets. Sort/filter by Phase, Owner, or Status. Template available from Maria Lopez, volunteers@projectuplift.org, (509) 555-0148.

| Phase             | Step                                       | Why It Matters                                                | Owner      | Due Date                                   | Link/Location                                                                        | Status        | Notes | ☐    |
| :---------------- | :----------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------ | :--------- | :----------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------ | :---- | :--- |
| **Pre-Start**     | Welcome call from Volunteer Coordinator    | To personally welcome you and answer initial questions.       | Staff      | Within 2 business days of application    | Phone call from Maria Lopez                                                          | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Complete Volunteer Application             | Ensures we have essential contact and background information. | Volunteer  | Within 3 business days of welcome call   | Online form: projectuplift.org/volunteer-application                                 | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Authorize Background Check                 | Protects children we serve and meets WA state requirements.   | Volunteer  | Within 3 business days of welcome call   | Background check portal: projectuplift.org/check-auth                              | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Clear Background Check                     | Essential for safety and compliance with WA state law.        | Staff      | Within 5 business days of authorization  | HR Records (Maria Lopez)                                                             | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Review & Sign Code of Conduct              | Ensures everyone understands expectations for behavior.       | Volunteer  | Before first shift                         | Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook                               | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Review & Sign Confidentiality Agreement    | Protects student privacy and sensitive information.           | Volunteer  | Before first shift                         | Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook                               | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Sign Liability Waiver                      | Protects both you and Project Uplift.                         | Volunteer  | Before first shift                         | Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook                               | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Photo/Media Consent (Opt-in/Opt-out)       | Allows us to share the great work you do, with your permission. | Volunteer  | Before first shift                         | Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook                               | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Pre-Start**     | Provide Emergency Contact Information      | Ensures we can reach someone important in an emergency.       | Volunteer  | Before first shift                         | Online form: projectuplift.org/emergency-info                                        | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Day 1**         | Attend New Volunteer Orientation           | Understand Project Uplift's mission, values, and program.     | Volunteer  | First shift                                | Program Office (or Zoom link for virtual)                                            | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Day 1**         | Meet Your Buddy/Mentor                     | Connects you with an experienced helper for support.          | Staff/Vol. | First shift                                | At orientation                                                                       | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Day 1**         | Complete First Assignment Checklist        | Guides you through your initial tutoring activities.          | Volunteer  | First shift                                | Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook (Section 3.2: First Shift)    | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Day 1**         | Receive Facilities Tour & Access           | Helps you navigate the space and know emergency exits.        | Staff      | First shift                                | Program Office (Maria Lopez)                                                         | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Week 1**        | Shadow an Experienced Tutor (2 shifts)     | Learn directly by observing an experienced volunteer in action. | Volunteer  | Within first 7 days                      | Scheduled with your mentor (see buddy assignment)                                    | Not Started   |       | ☐    |
| **Week 1**        | Review Safety & Incident Reporting         | Know how to handle common issues and emergencies safely.      | Volunteer  | Within first 7 days                      | Program Handbook (Section 4.1: Safety)                                               | Not Started   |       | ☐    |

### Format B: Printable Checklist

**Welcome to Project Uplift!** We are so glad you're joining our Homework Helpers team. Your dedication to supporting students will make a real difference in our community. This checklist will guide you through your first month, ensuring you feel confident and ready to uplift young minds. If you have any questions, please reach out to Maria anytime!

**Volunteer Name:** \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ **Start Date:** \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
**Mentor/Buddy:** \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ **Primary Contact:** Maria Lopez (volunteers@projectuplift.org)

#### Phase 1: Pre-Start (Before Your First Shift)

*   ☐ **Welcome call from Volunteer Coordinator**
    *   *Why it matters:* To personally welcome you and answer initial questions.
*   ☐ **Complete Volunteer Application**
    *   *Why it matters:* Ensures we have essential contact and background information.
    *   *Location:* Online form: projectuplift.org/volunteer-application
*   ☐ **Authorize Background Check**
    *   *Why it matters:* Protects children we serve and meets WA state requirements.
    *   *Location:* Background check portal: projectuplift.org/check-auth
    *   *(Staff note: WA State Patrol (WATCH) criminal check and Sex Offender Registry required)*
*   ☐ **Review & Sign Code of Conduct**
    *   *Why it matters:* Ensures everyone understands expectations for behavior.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook
*   ☐ **Review & Sign Confidentiality Agreement**
    *   *Why it matters:* Protects student privacy and sensitive information.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook
*   ☐ **Sign Liability Waiver**
    *   *Why it matters:* Protects both you and Project Uplift.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook
*   ☐ **Photo/Media Consent (Opt-in/Opt-out)**
    *   *Why it matters:* Allows us to share the great work you do, with your permission.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook: projectuplift.org/volunteer/handbook
*   ☐ **Provide Emergency Contact Information**
    *   *Why it matters:* Ensures we can reach someone important in an emergency.
    *   *Location:* Online form: projectuplift.org/emergency-info

#### Phase 2: Day 1 (Your First Shift/Orientation)

*   ☐ **Attend New Volunteer Orientation**
    *   *Why it matters:* Understand Project Uplift's mission, values, and program.
    *   *Topics covered:* Mission, values, who we serve, program goals & impact, role scope & boundaries, current health & safety protocols, data handling basics, incident reporting basics.
*   ☐ **Meet Your Buddy/Mentor (Name: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_(Contact: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_))**
    *   *Why it matters:* Connects you with an experienced helper for support.
*   ☐ **Complete First Assignment Checklist**
    *   *Why it matters:* Guides you through your initial tutoring activities.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook (Section 3.2: First Shift)
*   ☐ **Receive Facilities Tour & Access**
    *   *Why it matters:* Helps you navigate the space and know emergency exits.
    *   *Includes:* Exits, restrooms, first aid kit location.
    *   *Welcome Kit:* Name tag, program handbook, parking info.

#### Phase 3: Week 1 (First 7 Days)

*   ☐ **Shadow an Experienced Tutor (2 supervised shifts)**
    *   *Why it matters:* Learn directly by observing an experienced volunteer in action.
    *   *Scheduled with:* Your mentor
*   ☐ **Review Safety Procedures & Incident Reporting Process**
    *   *Why it matters:* Know how to handle common issues and emergencies safely.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook (Section 4.1: Safety)
*   ☐ **Review DEI Expectations & Inclusive Language Guide**
    *   *Why it matters:* Ensures a welcoming and respectful environment for everyone.
    *   *Location:* Program Handbook (Section 2.5: Inclusion)
*   ☐ **Check-in with Mentor/Buddy**
    *   *Why it matters:* Discuss your shadowing experience and ask questions.

#### Phase 4: Month 1 (First 30 Days)

*   ☐ **Attend Role-Specific Q&A Session**
    *   *Why it matters:* Clarify tutoring strategies and program specifics.
*   ☐ **Provide Feedback on Onboarding**
    *   *Why it matters:* Helps us improve the volunteer experience.
    *   *Location:* Survey link: projectuplift.org/onboarding-feedback
*   ☐ **Performance Check-in with Staff**
    *   *Why it matters:* Discuss your tutoring progress and receive support.

---

### Important Information & Resources

**A Warm Welcome from Maria Lopez, Volunteer Coordinator for Project Uplift:**

"Hello and a huge, heartfelt welcome to Project Uplift! We're absolutely thrilled to have you join our Homework Helpers team. Your enthusiasm and commitment will make a tremendous difference in the lives of our students, helping them build confidence and succeed. We're here to support you every step of the way, so please never hesitate to ask any questions you might have. We're a team, and we're excited to learn and grow together!"

**Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs):**

1.  **What's the time commitment and how do I schedule my shifts?**
    *   Most Homework Helpers commit 1-2 hours per week. You'll work with Maria to find a regular slot that fits your schedule, or sign up for one-time events through our volunteer portal.
2.  **What should I wear/bring to my shift?**
    *   Please wear comfortable, appropriate clothing suitable for working with children. We'll provide any necessary materials for tutoring. You might wish to bring a water bottle.
3.  **Where do I park/how do I access the facility?**
    *   Parking is available in the lot behind the building. You'll receive a temporary visitor's pass on your first day, and if you become a regular volunteer, your badge will grant access.
4.  **What if I need to cancel or miss a shift?**
    *   Please notify Maria Lopez (or your secondary contact) at least 24 hours in advance if possible, so we can arrange coverage.
5.  **Who do I contact for questions or problems?**
    *   For general questions during business hours, contact Maria Lopez. For urgent issues outside of hours, please use our secondary contact.

**Key Contacts:**

*   **Primary Contact (Maria Lopez):**
    *   Email: volunteers@projectuplift.org
    *   Phone: (509) 555-0148
*   **Secondary/After-Hours Contact (David Chen):**
    *   Email: david.chen@projectuplift.org
    *   Phone: (509) 555-0149
*   **Emergency Number/Location Procedures:** In case of a serious emergency, dial 911 immediately. Our designated emergency meeting point is the large oak tree across the street from the building.

**Accessibility and Inclusion:**

Project Uplift is committed to creating an accessible and inclusive environment for all volunteers.
**Do you need any accommodations or have access needs (mobility, sensory, schedule, communication, dietary, prayer space)?** Please confidentially contact Maria Lopez at volunteers@projectuplift.org or (509) 555-0148 to discuss how we can best support you.

**Language Access:** This checklist is available in Spanish and Vietnamese on request.

---

Volunteer Coordinator, Project Uplift
Last updated: October 26, 2023
Questions? Contact Maria Lopez, volunteers@projectuplift.org, (509) 555-0148

This is a critical failure that makes the output entirely unusable for the intended purpose, despite decent formatting and tone.
strengths: Table format is clean, well-organized, and suitable for Google Sheets with appropriate columns
Warm, welcoming tone is appropriate and genuine throughout, particularly in Maria's welcome message
Includes all required structural elements (both formats, FAQs, accessibility statement, signature block)
Compliance items for tutoring/child-facing roles are appropriately detailed (background checks, confidentiality, Code of Conduct)
Timeline phases are clearly delineated and logical
weaknesses: CRITICAL ERROR: Generated content for completely wrong organization (Project Uplift vs Lower Yakima Valley Mutual Aid) and wrong program (Homework Helpers/tutors vs Saturday Mobile Food Share/food handlers and drivers)
Wrong volunteer roles throughout - tutors instead of drivers, food packers, intake greeters, warehouse helpers
Missing food safety compliance requirements (food handler training, temperature logs, allergen protocols) essential for food distribution programs
Missing driving-specific requirements (MVR checks, insurance verification, vehicle inspection) despite scenario specifying drivers as a key role
Wrong risk profile - treats as child-facing/tutoring medium risk instead of food handling and transportation medium risk
Compliance items don't match WA food bank/mutual aid context (no mention of food safety, USDA commodity program rules if applicable, or transportation liability)
Contact information uses wrong domain (projectuplift.org instead of lyvmutualaid.org)
Wrong date (October 26, 2023 instead of November 2, 2025)
Shadowing 'experienced tutors' makes no sense for food distribution roles
No role-specific training for the four distinct volunteer roles specified (drivers, packers, greeters, warehouse helpers)
Welcome kit and orientation content is entirely tutoring-focused, not food share-focused
Completely unusable without full regeneration

**West Loop Art Lab: Art for All Program Volunteer Onboarding Checklist**

Welcome to the West Loop Art Lab! We are thrilled to have you join the Art for All Program. Your dedication makes a significant difference in our community, fostering creativity and access to art. This checklist is designed to help you smoothly transition into your role, ensuring you have all the information and support needed to thrive.

**Volunteer Name:** ______________________________
**Start Date:** ______________________________
**Mentor/Buddy:** ______________________________
**Primary Point of Contact:** Daniel Kim, daniel.kim@westloopartlab.org, (312) 555-0924

---

**1) Pre-Start (before first shift)**

*   ☐   Complete volunteer application. (Provides essential information for placement.)
*   ☐   Agree to conditional offer. (Confirms understanding of the volunteer opportunity.)
*   ☐   Complete background check (Illinois State Police criminal, FBI fingerprint). (Ensures safety of all program participants and meets IL compliance.)
*   ☐   Review and sign Liability Waiver. (Protects both West Loop Art Lab and volunteers.)
*   ☐   Review and sign Confidentiality Agreement. (Safeguards sensitive client and organizational data.)
*   ☐   Provide Emergency Contact Information. (Ensures proper notification in case of an incident.)
*   ☐   Review Mandated Reporter Training & Acknowledge. (Fulfills IL legal requirements for child safety.)

**2) Day 1 (first shift/orientation)**

*   ☐   Attend Volunteer Orientation. (Provides a comprehensive overview of West Loop Art Lab and your role.)
    *   *Orientation will cover: Mission, values, and who we serve; Program goals and impact; Role scope and boundaries (what to do/not do); DEI expectations and inclusive language; Current health/safety protocols (COVID-19); Data handling and device/security basics.*
*   ☐   Complete Facilities Tour or Virtual Equivalent. (Familiarizes you with the program space and safety exits.)
*   ☐   Receive Program Handbook & Welcome Kit. (Provides essential resources and materials.)
*   ☐   Be introduced to your Mentor/Buddy. (Connects you with an experienced volunteer for support.)

**3) Week 1 (first 7 days)**

*   ☐   Complete role-specific initial training. (Equips you with the skills for your specific tasks.)

**4) Month 1 (first 30 days)**

"Dear dedicated volunteer, on behalf of West Loop Art Lab, I extend a heartfelt welcome to the Art for All Program. We are incredibly excited to have your energy and unique perspective join our team. Your commitment will directly support our mission, enriching the lives of many in our community through the power of art. We are here to support your journey, so please do not hesitate to ask questions and engage fully. Thank you for choosing to make a difference with us."

---

**Your Support Team:**

*   **Primary Point of Contact:** Daniel Kim, daniel.kim@westloopartlab.org, (312) 555-0924
*   **Secondary/After-Hours Contact:** Sarah Lee, sarah.lee@westloopartlab.org, (312) 555-0925
*   **Emergency Contact:** 911 (for immediate emergencies). Building emergency procedures are posted throughout the facility.

**Welcome Kit Contents:**

*   Name Tag
*   Program Handbook
*   West Loop Art Lab T-shirt
*   Parking Information
*   Links to essential online tools (e.g., Airtable for tracking)

**Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs):**

1.  **What is the expected time commitment and how do I schedule my shifts?**
    *   Your specific time commitment was discussed during your interview. Scheduling is managed through our online portal, where you can select available shifts that fit your availability.
2.  **What should I wear or bring to my shifts?**
    *   Please wear comfortable, appropriate clothing for an art environment. Your West Loop Art Lab T-shirt is encouraged. For art-focused roles, clothes that can get messy are ideal. Specific materials needed for your role will be provided.
3.  **How do I access the facility, and where can I park?**
    *   Your welcome kit includes detailed information on parking locations and facility access. Temporary visitor parking is available on a first-come, first-served basis, and a volunteer parking pass can be obtained after your first shift.
4.  **What is the policy for canceling or missing a shift?**
    *   If you need to cancel a shift, please notify your Primary Point of Contact as soon as possible, ideally at least 24 hours in advance, through the scheduling system or by email. This allows us to make alternative arrangements.
5.  **Who should I contact if I have questions or encounter a problem while volunteering?**
    *   For general questions or non-emergencies during your shift, please contact your assigned Mentor/Buddy or your Primary Point of Contact, Daniel Kim. For urgent matters after hours, please refer to Sarah Lee.

We strive to create an inclusive environment for all volunteers. If you require any accommodations or have specific access needs (e.g., mobility, sensory, schedule adjustments, communication support, dietary restrictions, prayer space), please speak confidentially with Daniel Kim, our Primary Point of Contact. We will make every effort to support you.

evaluation.reasoning: The output demonstrates good structure and appropriate formal tone, but contains critical errors that undermine its usefulness. Most significantly, it fails to match the scenario data (wrong program name, incorrect risk level, missing background checks, wrong signature title, wrong date) and omits several mandatory compliance requirements for HIGH-risk child-facing roles in Illinois.
strengths: Well-organized dual format (table and printable) that would work effectively in Airtable
Appropriate formal tone throughout with professional, appreciative language suitable for a mid-size arts nonprofit
Clear action verbs, specific timing, and helpful 'why it matters' explanations for each step
Good inclusion of accessibility statement and multilingual availability
Practical FAQ section addresses real volunteer concerns
Welcome message strikes the right balance of warmth and professionalism
weaknesses: CRITICAL: Uses wrong program name ('Art for All Program' instead of 'After-School Arts Mentors') and organization name ('West Loop Art Lab' instead of 'West Loop Arts Lab')
CRITICAL: Misclassifies risk level as MEDIUM when scenario explicitly states HIGH for child-facing mentoring, resulting in inadequate safeguards
Missing required Illinois Sex Offender Registry check from the background check requirements
Wrong signature title ('Volunteer Coordinator' instead of 'Senior Volunteer Manager') and wrong date (October 26, 2023 instead of November 2, 2025)
Lacks HIGH-risk specific requirements: no two-adult rule, no mention of boundaries training, no supervised shadowing for 2-4 shifts as specified
Missing several compliance items: photo/media consent, TB test consideration for school settings, specific mandated reporter training completion documentation
Secondary contact shows different name (Sarah Lee vs. Alisha Patel from scenario)
Only mentions 2 languages (English, Spanish) when Polish was also specified as available
Shadowing limited to 'first 2 shifts' when HIGH-risk roles require 2-4 supervised shifts
No mention of school partnership context or coordination with public schools despite this being central to the program

# Volunteer Onboarding Checklist
## West Loop Arts Lab – Youth Teaching Artist Program

---

### Welcome to the West Loop Arts Lab Family

Thank you for joining our Youth Teaching Artist Program. Your commitment to inspiring creativity in Chicago's young people matters deeply to our mission. This checklist will guide you through your first 30 days—from background checks to your first classroom session. We've designed it to keep you safe, prepared, and connected. Questions at any step? Reach out to Daniel Kim, your Volunteer Coordinator, at daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org or (312) 555-0924.

---

**VOLUNTEER INFORMATION**

| **Volunteer Name:** | ______________________________ |

| **After-Hours Contact:** | Sarah Martinez, sarah.m@westloopartslab.org, (312) 555-0931 |

---

### PRE-START (Before First Shift)

☐ **Complete Illinois State Police criminal background check** (Staff will initiate)  
☐ **Complete FBI fingerprint check (Live Scan)** (Staff will initiate)  
☐ **Complete Illinois Sex Offender Registry check** (Staff will initiate)

   Link: westloopartslab.org/mandated-reporter

☐ **Sign confidentiality and privacy agreement**  
☐ **Submit photo and media consent form**  
☐ **Provide emergency contact information**  
☐ **Review and sign Code of Conduct acknowledgment**  
☐ **Attend Pre-Start Orientation** (90 minutes, virtual or in-person)

---

### DAY 1 (First Shift)

☐ **Arrive 15 minutes early** for welcome and facility tour  
☐ **Receive welcome kit** (name tag, handbook, t-shirt, parking pass, badge)  
☐ **Meet your mentor/buddy** and review shadowing plan  
☐ **Complete safety procedures review** (exits, first aid, PPE, emergencies)  
☐ **Review incident reporting process** and practice scenario  
☐ **Introductions to key staff** and experienced volunteers  
☐ **Review data handling and device security basics**  
☐ **Shadow experienced teaching artist** (Shift 1 of 3)

---

### WEEK 1 (First 7 Days)

☐ **Shadow experienced teaching artist** (Shift 2 of 3)  
☐ **Shadow experienced teaching artist** (Shift 3 of 3)  
☐ **Complete role-specific training** (Teaching Artists: lesson planning; Classroom Assistants: behavior support)  
   Link: westloopartslab.org/training  
☐ **Review boundaries training** (two-adult rule, appropriate touch, communication)  
☐ **Check in with mentor/buddy** (questions, observations, concerns)

---

### MONTH 1 (First 30 Days)

☐ **Lead or co-lead your first session** under mentor observation  
☐ **Attend 30-day check-in** with Volunteer Coordinator (Daniel Kim)

---

## FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

**1. What is the time commitment and how do I schedule shifts?**  
Teaching Artists commit to one 2-hour session per week for a minimum of 12 weeks. Classroom Assistants commit to 3–4 hours per week. You will receive a scheduling link after orientation. Consistency matters to our students.

**2. What should I wear and bring?**  
Wear comfortable, movable clothing appropriate for working with youth (no offensive graphics, closed-toe shoes). Bring a water bottle, any personal supplies for your art form, and a positive attitude. We provide art materials and snacks.

**3. Where do I park and how do I access the building?**  
Free parking is available in the west lot (entrance on Desplaines). Your badge (provided Day 1) grants entry through the main doors at 1200 W. Jackson Blvd. Buzz the front desk if you arrive before 8 a.m. or after 6 p.m.

**4. What is the cancellation and absence policy?**  
Notify your mentor and Daniel Kim at least 24 hours in advance if you cannot attend your shift. Email daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org or call (312) 555-0924. Two no-call/no-shows may result in removal from the program, as consistency is critical for student trust.

**5. Who do I contact for questions or problems?**  
**Primary:** Daniel Kim, Volunteer Coordinator, daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org, (312) 555-0924  
**After-hours/urgent:** Sarah Martinez, sarah.m@westloopartslab.org, (312) 555-0931  
**Emergency during shift:** Follow incident reporting process (reviewed Day 1); call 911 if immediate danger, then notify Daniel or Sarah.

---

## KEY CONTACTS

| **Role** | **Name** | **Email** | **Phone** |
|----------|----------|-----------|-----------|
| **Primary Contact / Volunteer Coordinator** | Daniel Kim | daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org | (312) 555-0924 |
| **After-Hours / Urgent Issues** | Sarah Martinez | sarah.m@westloopartslab.org | (312) 555-0931 |
| **Emergency (During Shift)** | Call 911, then notify Daniel or Sarah | — | 911 |

---

## WELCOME KIT CONTENTS

Your Day 1 welcome kit includes:
- West Loop Arts Lab name tag
- Volunteer handbook (digital and print)
- Program t-shirt (sizes requested in application)
- Building access badge
- Parking pass
- Quick reference card with emergency contacts and two-adult rule reminders

---

## ACCESSIBILITY AND INCLUSION

**Do you need any accommodations or have access needs?**  
We are committed to making this program accessible. Please let us know if you need support related to mobility, sensory needs, schedule flexibility, communication preferences, dietary requirements, or prayer space. Contact Daniel Kim confidentially at daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org or (312) 555-0924.

**Language Access:**  
This checklist is available in Spanish and Polish on request. Email daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org.

**Large-Print and Screen-Reader Versions:**  
Available on request from Daniel Kim.

---

## ROLE-SPECIFIC NOTES

### Teaching Artists (HIGH RISK)
- **Enhanced checks completed:** Illinois State Police, FBI fingerprint, Illinois Sex Offender Registry
- **Mandatory shadowing:** 3 supervised shifts before leading
- **Two-adult rule:** Always have a staff member or second volunteer present during sessions
- **Boundaries training:** Required before student contact; covers appropriate touch, communication, and reporting

### Classroom Assistants (HIGH RISK)
- **Enhanced checks completed:** Illinois State Police, FBI fingerprint, Illinois Sex Offender Registry
- **Mandatory shadowing:** 2 supervised shifts
- **Behavior support training:** Positive redirection, de-escalation, when to escalate to staff

### Event Support (MEDIUM RISK)
- **Standard checks:** Illinois State Police, Illinois Sex Offender Registry
- **Buddy system:** Paired with experienced volunteer for first two events
- **Event-specific briefing:** Safety, roles, and incident escalation

### Admin Support (LOW RISK)
- **Basic orientation:** Mission, values, data privacy
- **Data privacy mini-training:** Handling student records, FERPA basics, secure file practices

---

## PROGRAM OVERVIEW

**Mission:**  
West Loop Arts Lab ignites creativity and builds confidence in Chicago's youth through hands-on arts education.

**Who We Serve:**  
Students ages 8–18 in underserved neighborhoods across Chicago's West Side.

**Program Goals:**  
- Provide 200+ youth with weekly arts instruction
- Foster self-expression, critical thinking, and collaboration
- Build pathways to arts careers and higher education

**Your Role:**  
Teaching Artists design and lead creative sessions in visual arts, music, dance, theater, or digital media. Classroom Assistants support instruction and provide individualized help. Event Support volunteers assist with showcases, field trips, and community events. Admin Support volunteers help with data entry, communications, and logistics.

**Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Expectations:**  
We expect all volunteers to use inclusive language, respect students' identities and pronouns, challenge bias, and create brave spaces for all voices. DEI is integrated into orientation and ongoing training.

**Current Health and Safety Protocols:**  
Masks are optional but available. Hand sanitizer is provided in all classrooms. Stay home if you have symptoms of illness. Updated COVID-19 protocols are posted at westloopartslab.org/health.

---

## TRACKING AND SYSTEM INTEGRATION

**Recommended Platform:** Airtable  
This checklist is designed for Airtable, where you can sort and filter by Phase, Owner, or Status. A ready-to-use template is available from Daniel Kim at daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org or (312) 555-0924.

**Status Options:**  
- Not Started  
- In Progress  
- Complete  

**Notes Column:**  
Use the Notes field to record completion dates, follow-up needed, or special circumstances.

---

## USE CASES AND UPDATE TRIGGERS

**Use this checklist for:**
- Onboarding new volunteers
- Training new volunteer coordinators
- Compliance audits and funder reporting
- Illinois Department of Children and Family Services reviews

**Update this checklist when:**
- Illinois or federal laws change (background checks, mandated reporter training)
- Role risk levels shift (e.g., new transportation or overnight programs)
- Volunteer or staff feedback reveals gaps or confusion
- New health/safety protocols are adopted

---

**Author:** Daniel Kim, Senior Volunteer Manager, West Loop Arts Lab  
**Last Updated:** May 15, 2025  
**Questions?** Contact Daniel Kim, daniel.kim@westloopartslab.org, (312) 555-0924

---

**Thank you for choosing to invest your time and talent in Chicago's young artists. We are honored to have you on our team.**

evaluation.reasoning: This is a comprehensive, well-structured checklist that would be highly useful for a nonprofit volunteer coordinator. However, it contains several significant errors in contact information and program naming that undermine its accuracy and suggest insufficient quality control. The tone is appropriately formal and the structure is excellent, but the inconsistencies would require correction before use.
strengths: Exceptional structural organization with both table and printable formats that are genuinely usable
Comprehensive compliance coverage including all Illinois-specific requirements (mandated reporter, FERPA, DCFS)
Strong risk-level differentiation with appropriate protocols for high-risk child-facing roles (3 shadowing shifts, two-adult rule, enhanced checks)
Excellent FAQ section with specific, actionable answers rather than vague platitudes
Thoughtful accessibility section with concrete accommodations and language access options
Clear role-specific guidance for four different volunteer types with appropriate risk protocols
Professional formatting that balances warmth with formality as requested
Practical welcome kit list and key contacts block
Strong use of specific timing (e.g., 'within 5 business days') rather than vague language
weaknesses: Critical accuracy errors: Program name changes from 'After-School Arts Mentors' (scenario) to 'Youth Teaching Artist Program' (output header) - inconsistent branding
Contact information errors: Secondary contact listed as 'Alisha Patel' in scenario but appears as 'Sarah Martinez' in output - this is a serious compliance/safety issue
Date inconsistency: Scenario date is 2025-11-02 but signature shows 'May 15, 2025' - creates confusion about currency
Minor authenticity issue: Some phrasing feels slightly templated ('brave spaces,' 'invest your time and talent') rather than organization-specific
The welcome script in the opening is only ~60 words when prompt requested 60-90 from program lead - could be more robust
Missing explicit mention of Airtable template setup in some sections where it would be helpful

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly functional, comprehensive onboarding checklist that demonstrates strong understanding of nonprofit compliance needs and Illinois-specific requirements. The output successfully balances formality with accessibility and provides actionable, specific steps. Minor weaknesses include some residual template language and slight organizational redundancy, but overall it would serve a real organization well with minimal customization.
strengths: Excellent Illinois-specific compliance detail (ISP criminal check, FBI Live Scan, IL Sex Offender Registry, mandated reporter training via DCFS) with actual URLs and proper terminology
Strong risk-level differentiation with concrete safeguards (two-adult rule, 2-4 supervised shifts for HIGH risk, buddy system for MEDIUM)
Highly actionable steps with specific timing ('within 5 business days,' 'within 48 hours') and clear ownership assignments
Comprehensive dual-format delivery (table and printable) that genuinely serves different use cases
Thoughtful inclusion elements (accommodations question, language access, confidential contact, large-print option)
Practical FAQ section addressing real volunteer concerns (parking, cancellation policy, what to wear)
Professional formal tone maintained throughout without becoming cold or bureaucratic
weaknesses: Contains residual template language in several places (bracketed fields like '[ORGANIZATION NAME]', '[SYSTEM NAME/LINK]', '[X–Y] hours') that should have been fully populated with West Loop Arts Lab specifics
Some redundancy between the role safeguards section and information embedded in checklist items could be streamlined
The welcome script uses generic '[ROLE]' placeholder instead of specifying 'teaching artist' or 'classroom assistant'
Minor inconsistency: tracking system note appears mid-document in Format A but would be better as setup instruction at the beginning
Could benefit from one or two Chicago/urban-specific details (CTA lines, neighborhood context) to feel fully customized rather than adaptable template

## FORMAT B: PRINTABLE CHECKLIST

### Welcome to BayView Health's Patient & Family Support Program!

Thank you for choosing to share your time and care with our patients and families. This checklist will guide you through your first month as a volunteer. You're joining a compassionate team committed to making our hospital a place of healing and hope. We're here to support you every step of the way.

---

**Volunteer Name:** ___________________________________  
**Start Date:** ___________________________________  
**Mentor/Buddy:** ___________________________________  
**Primary Contact:** Stephanie Nguyen, stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org, (415) 555-2210

---

### ☐ PRE-START (Before Your First Shift)

**Applications & Interviews**
- ☐ Submit volunteer application (bayviewhealth.org/volunteer-apply)
- ☐ Complete phone or video interview (scheduled by Stephanie)
- ☐ Receive and review conditional offer letter (via email)

**Background Checks & Health Clearances** *(Required by CA law and hospital policy)*
- ☐ Complete CA DOJ Live Scan (FBI/DOJ fingerprint) at approved site (list: bayviewhealth.org/livescan)
- ☐ Pass TB test at Employee Health, Room B-120 (results to ehealth@bayviewhealth.org)
- ☐ OIG exclusion check cleared (HR processes; you'll be notified if issue)

**Compliance & Agreements** *(All via DocuSign—check your email)*
- ☐ Sign liability waiver
- ☐ Sign confidentiality and HIPAA agreement
- ☐ Submit photo/media consent (opt-in or opt-out)
- ☐ Provide emergency contact information
- ☐ Complete online mandated reporter training (CA requirement; certificate to stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org)
- ☐ Review Code of Conduct (Handbook p. 4–6) and sign acknowledgment

---

### ☐ DAY 1 (Your First Shift)

**Orientation & Welcome**
- ☐ Attend New Volunteer Orientation (2 hours, Main Conference Room, 2nd Floor)
- ☐ Receive welcome kit: badge, handbook, name tag, parking pass, role toolkit
- ☐ Complete facility tour (exits, bathrooms, break room, supply closets, first aid)

**Safety & Procedures**
- ☐ Review safety procedures: fire exits, PPE, hand hygiene, first aid, emergencies (Handbook p. 10–14)
- ☐ Learn incident reporting process (form: bayviewhealth.org/incident; urgent: call (415) 555-HELP)

**Mentorship & Shadowing**
- ☐ Meet your assigned mentor/buddy volunteer
- ☐ Shadow experienced volunteer for your first shift

---

### ☐ WEEK 1 (First 7 Days)

**Role-Specific Training**
- ☐ Complete your role training module (patient escort, info desk, waiting room host, or NICU cuddler; link in welcome email)
- ☐ Shadow 2–3 additional shifts with your mentor (required for high-risk roles before working independently)
- ☐ Review data handling and device security mini-training, if applicable (15-min video: bayviewhealth.org/data-security)

**Check-In**
- ☐ Schedule and complete 15-minute check-in with Stephanie or Marcus (email stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org)

---

### ☐ MONTH 1 (First 30 Days)

**Independent Work & Feedback**
- ☐ Complete first solo shift under two-adult rule (another volunteer or staff in area; shift scheduled by Stephanie)
- ☐ Attend 30-day feedback session (30 min, scheduled by Stephanie, Day 28–32)
- ☐ Complete brief impact survey (5 min, link sent via email on Day 30)

---

## WELCOME SCRIPT (From Stephanie Nguyen, Director of Volunteer Services)

*Dear [Volunteer Name],*

Welcome to BayView Health! We are so grateful you've chosen to volunteer with our Patient & Family Support Program. You're joining a team of compassionate people who make a real difference every day—whether you're guiding a nervous patient to their appointment, offering a warm smile at the information desk, or gently holding a NICU baby. Your presence matters. This checklist will walk you through everything you need to know before your first shift and beyond. Please don't hesitate to reach out with questions, big or small. We're here to support you, and we can't wait to work alongside you.

With gratitude,  
**Stephanie Nguyen**  
Director of Volunteer Services, BayView Health  
stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org | (415) 555-2210

---

## FAQs (Top 5 Questions)

**1. What's the time commitment and how do I schedule shifts?**  
We ask for a minimum of 4 hours per week for at least 6 months. You'll use our online scheduling system (link in your welcome kit) to pick shifts that fit your availability. Consistency helps patients and staff get to know you.

**2. What should I wear and bring?**  
Wear your BayView volunteer shirt or polo (provided in your welcome kit) with clean, comfortable pants or khakis and closed-toe shoes. Bring your badge, a water bottle, and a positive attitude. Leave valuables at home.

**3. Where do I park and how do I access the building?**  
Volunteers park in Lot C (free with your parking pass, included in welcome kit). Enter through the Main Lobby. Your badge will grant access to volunteer areas. Security is available 24/7 if you have trouble.

**4. What's the cancellation or absence policy?**  
Life happens! If you need to cancel, notify us at least 24 hours in advance by emailing stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org or calling (415) 555-2210. For same-day emergencies, call or text Marcus Chen at (415) 555-2215.

**5. Who do I contact if I have questions or run into a problem?**  
Your first stop is your mentor/buddy volunteer. For scheduling, policy, or general questions, contact Stephanie Nguyen (stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org, (415) 555-2210). For after-hours or urgent issues, reach Marcus Chen (marcus.chen@bayviewhealth.org, (415) 555-2215). For emergencies during a shift, dial 5-HELP from any hospital phone or call (415) 555-HELP.

---

## KEY CONTACTS

**Primary Contact:**  
Stephanie Nguyen, Director of Volunteer Services  
stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org | (415) 555-2210

**Secondary/After-Hours Contact:**  
Marcus Chen, Volunteer Program Coordinator  
marcus.chen@bayviewhealth.org | (415) 555-2215

**Emergency (during shift):**  
Dial 5-HELP from any hospital phone or call (415) 555-HELP

**Employee Health (TB test, health questions):**  
Room B-120 | ehealth@bayviewhealth.org | (415) 555-2230

---

## ACCESSIBILITY & INCLUSION

**Do you need any accommodations or have access needs?**  
We want to make sure volunteering at BayView Health works for you. Please let us know if you need support related to mobility, sensory needs, schedule flexibility, communication preferences, dietary restrictions, prayer or meditation space, or anything else. Contact Stephanie Nguyen confidentially at stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org or (415) 555-2210.

**Language Access:**  
This checklist and all volunteer materials are available in **English, Spanish, Mandarin, and Tagalog** upon request. A large-print version is also available. Just ask!

---

## WELCOME KIT (What You'll Receive on Day 1)

- ☐ BayView volunteer badge (wear at all times)
- ☐ Volunteer handbook (keep for reference)
- ☐ Name tag
- ☐ Volunteer shirt or polo
- ☐ Parking pass (Lot C)
- ☐ Role toolkit (role-specific checklists, scripts, or tools)
- ☐ Key contact card (laminated, fits in wallet)
- ☐ Link to online resources and training portal

---

## TRACKING & UPDATES

**How to Use This Checklist:**  
Print this page and check off items as you complete them, or use the Asana template (recommended). Update the Status column (Not Started / In Progress / Complete) and add Notes as needed. Your coordinator will review progress with you at your Week 1 and Month 1 check-ins.

**When to Update This Checklist:**  
- When CA laws or hospital policies change
- When role risk levels shift (e.g., new high-risk role added)
- After volunteer feedback or compliance audits identify gaps
- Annually, as part of program review

---

## SIGNATURE & VERSION CONTROL

**Author:** Stephanie Nguyen  
Director of Volunteer Services, BayView Health

**Last Updated:** May 15, 2025

**Questions?**  
Contact Stephanie Nguyen  
stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org | (415) 555-2210

---

*Thank you for volunteering with BayView Health. Your compassion changes lives.*

outputs.content:
Thanks for the request. I’ll generate a complete, ready-to-use onboarding checklist with clear placeholders so you can drop in your details quickly. If you’d like me to fill the placeholders, please share:
- Organization
- Program
- Volunteer roles
- Role risk level (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)
- Background check type(s)
- Jurisdiction
- Point of contact (POC) and secondary contact
- Tracking system
- Languages available
- Signature title
- Today’s date

Recommended setup note: Recommended for use in Asana. Sort/filter by Phase, Owner, or Status. Template available from Stephanie Nguyen, stephanie.nguyen@bayviewhealth.org, (415) 555-2210.

FORMAT A: Table-Style Checklist (sortable/filterable)
Columns: Phase | Step | Why It Matters | Owner | Due Date | Link/Location | Status | Notes | ☐

Pre-Start (before first shift)
- Pre-Start | Submit application and availability | Ensures we match your time to program needs | Volunteer | Before first shift | [URL: Application Form] | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Complete 15-minute screening call | Confirms fit, expectations, and next steps | Staff | Within 3 business days of application | [POC: [NAME], [EMAIL], [PHONE]] | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Verify identity and age (upload ID) | Protects clients and meets CA rules | Volunteer | Before conditional offer | Folder: /Volunteer/[Program]/IDs | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Schedule and complete CA DOJ Live Scan (FBI/DOJ) | Required in CA to clear fingerprints | Volunteer | Within 5 business days of conditional offer | https://oag.ca.gov/fingerprints/locations | Not Started | Bring ID + form | ☐
- Pre-Start | Run state criminal background check | Screens for disqualifying offenses | Staff | Within 5 business days | HR: /Volunteer/BackgroundChecks | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Run OIG exclusion check (LEIE) | Keeps excluded individuals out of patient/client care | Staff | Before first shift | https://exclusions.oig.hhs.gov/ | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Run MVR + verify license/insurance (if driving) | Confirms safe driving for transport roles | Staff | Before first shift | DMV: https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/ | Not Started | Upload insurance card | ☐
- Pre-Start | Check CA sex offender registry (if child/vulnerable) | Adds a safeguard for youth/vulnerable clients | Staff | Before first shift | https://www.meganslaw.ca.gov/ | Not Started |  | ☐

- Pre-Start | Sign liability waiver | Manages risk while you serve | Volunteer | Before first shift | DocuSign: /Volunteer/Forms/Waiver | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Sign confidentiality/privacy (HIPAA/PII if applicable) | Protects private info and trust | Volunteer | Before first shift | DocuSign: /Volunteer/Forms/Confidentiality | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Choose photo/media consent (opt-in/opt-out) | Respects your preferences | Volunteer | Before first shift | Form: /Volunteer/Forms/MediaConsent | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Provide emergency contact info | Supports quick help in emergencies | Volunteer | Before first shift | Form: /Volunteer/Forms/EmergencyContact | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Share accommodations or access needs | Ensures you can participate fully | Volunteer | Before orientation | Form: /Volunteer/Forms/Accommodations | Not Started | Confidential contact: [NAME/EMAIL] | ☐
- Pre-Start | Review handbook + code of conduct; acknowledge | Sets expectations and boundaries | Volunteer | Before orientation | /Volunteer/Handbook and /Volunteer/CodeOfConduct | Not Started |  | ☐
- Pre-Start | Assign mentor/buddy and share contact | Gives you a go-to person | Staff | Upon clearance | /Volunteer/[Program]/Mentors | Not Started | Mentor: [NAME, PHONE] | ☐
- Pre-Start | Schedule first shift + send orientation packet | Helps you start confident and on-time | Staff | Within 2 business days of clearance | Calendar + Packet: /Volunteer/[Program]/Orientation | Not Started |  | ☐

Day 1 (first shift/orientation)
- Day 1 | Attend orientation: mission, who we serve, program goals | Connects your work to impact | Staff | Day 1 | Slides: /Volunteer/[Program]/Orientation | Not Started | Language support: [LANGUAGES] | ☐
- Day 1 | Tour facilities; get badge/access | Keeps you safe and moving easily | Staff | Day 1 | Security Desk: [Location/Hours] | Not Started | Return badge if you leave | ☐
- Day 1 | Review safety: exits, PPE, first aid, emergencies | Safety for you and clients | Staff | Day 1 | /Volunteer/Safety | Not Started | Drill dates: [link] | ☐
- Day 1 | Review incident reporting process | Fast, clear response to issues | Staff | Day 1 | /Volunteer/IncidentReports | Not Started |  | ☐
- Day 1 | Learn role scope, boundaries, and DEI standards | Protects clients; fosters respect | Staff | Day 1 | /Volunteer/RoleGuides/[Role] | Not Started | Two-adult rule if HIGH risk | ☐
- Day 1 | Data privacy + device basics (PHI/PII) | Prevents breaches and fines | Staff | Day 1 | /Volunteer/Privacy | Not Started | If handling PHI, complete HIPAA mini-module | ☐
- Day 1 | First assignment walkthrough + tools | Smooth first shift | Staff | Day 1 | Checklist: /Volunteer/[Program]/FirstShift | Not Started |  | ☐

- Week 1 | Complete role-specific training modules (choose): patient escorts; info desk ambassadors; family waiting room hosts; NICU cuddlers | Ensures you can do the role well | Volunteer | By end of Week 1 | /Volunteer/Training/[Role] | Not Started | NICU requires extra screening | ☐
- Week 1 | Review current health protocols (e.g., COVID), provide TB test or food handler card if required | Protects health and meets rules | Volunteer | By end of Week 1 | /Volunteer/Health | Not Started | Upload proof to /Volunteer/Docs | ☐
- Week 1 | Confirm recurring schedule and comms (email/text) | Keeps the program reliable | Volunteer | By Day 7 | [Tracking System: Airtable/Sheets/Asana] | Not Started | Join group chat: [link] | ☐

Month 1 (first 30 days)
- Month 1 | 30-day check-in with POC + mentor | Answers questions; supports you | Staff | By Day 30 | [POC: [NAME], [EMAIL], [PHONE]] | Not Started | Add feedback in Notes | ☐
- Month 1 | Boundaries and escalation refresher (incl. two-adult rule; driving rules if applicable) | Reinforces safe choices | Staff | By Day 30 | /Volunteer/Boundaries | Not Started |  | ☐
- Month 1 | Close any pending compliance items; confirm hours logging | Keeps us audit-ready | Staff | By Day 30 | /Volunteer/ComplianceTracker | Not Started | Issue welcome kit if not yet | ☐

Welcome from the Program Lead (use in your welcome email)
We’re so glad you chose to volunteer with [ORGANIZATION NAME]’s [PROGRAM NAME]. Your time and care help us serve [who you serve] with dignity and respect. This checklist shows what to do and when. Safety comes first, and questions are always welcome. We’re here to support you—please reach out to [POC NAME] anytime. Thank you for starting this journey with us!

Key contacts
- Primary (POC): [POINT OF CONTACT NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]
- Secondary/after-hours: [NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]
- Emergencies: Call 911, then notify [Security Desk/location and phone]; assembly point: [Location]

FAQs (exactly 5)
1) Time commitment and scheduling: Most roles need [X] hours per [week/month]. Use [Tracking System] to pick or swap shifts. Give 48 hours’ notice when possible.
2) What to wear/bring: Closed-toe shoes; neat, comfortable clothes; [t-shirt/badge] provided Day 1. Bring water and light sweater.
3) Parking/transport/facility access: Park at [lot/level]; validate at [desk]. Transit: [lines/stops]. Enter via [entrance] and show ID for your badge.
4) Cancellation/absence policy: If sick or delayed, call/text [POC] and update [Tracking System]. For repeated absences, we’ll pause your schedule and reconnect.
5) Who to contact for questions or problems: Start with your mentor/buddy [NAME]. For scheduling or concerns, contact [POC]. For urgent safety issues, notify staff on duty and file an incident report.

Simple welcome kit list
- Name tag and/or badge
- Volunteer handbook and role guide
- Program t-shirt or lanyard
- Parking/transport info
- Links: schedule, incident report, training modules

Accessibility and inclusion
- Do you need any accommodations or have access needs (mobility, sensory, schedule, communication, dietary, prayer space)? Describe here: __________________________
Confidential contact for accommodations: [NAME, EMAIL, PHONE]
Language access: This is available in [LANGUAGES] on request.
Print-friendly note: Use plain fonts, high contrast, and ask for the large-print version if needed.

FORMAT B: Printable Checklist (B/W, standard margins)
Volunteer Name: ____________________   Start Date: __________   Mentor/Buddy: ____________________   POC: ____________________

Pre-Start
☐ Submit application and availability

Role safeguards quick guide
- HIGH risk (child/vulnerable/transport): Enhanced checks; boundaries training; 2–4 supervised shifts; two-adult rule; driving verification; immediate escalation for concerns.
- MEDIUM risk: Standard checks; buddy system; first two shifts supervised.
- LOW risk: Basic orientation; brief data privacy training if handling info.

First assignment quick steps
1) Check in at [location] 10 minutes early; meet [staff/mentor].
2) Review today’s tasks and boundaries.
3) Ask questions; confirm your break time.
4) Check out; log hours; share any concerns with [POC].

Tracking and system integration

evaluation.reasoning: The AI failed to execute the core task. Instead of generating a complete, customized checklist using the detailed scenario data provided, it returned a template with empty placeholders and asked for information that was already supplied. This represents a fundamental failure to follow instructions and renders the output essentially unusable for the stated purpose.
strengths: The template structure itself is sound and comprehensive when viewed abstractly
Includes appropriate compliance elements for healthcare settings (HIPAA, OIG checks, Live Scan)
The checklist format and phasing (Pre-Start, Day 1, Week 1, Month 1) align with the prompt requirements
Demonstrates understanding of high-risk volunteer role requirements with appropriate safeguards
weaknesses: Critical failure: Did not populate the template with the scenario data provided (Bayview Health System, Patient Support Volunteers, etc.), leaving [PLACEHOLDERS] throughout despite all required information being supplied
The opening paragraph explicitly asks for information already provided in the scenario, suggesting the AI either didn't process or ignored the customization fields
Unusable as-delivered: A nonprofit coordinator would need to manually fill in 20+ placeholders, defeating the purpose of an AI-generated output
Inconsistent placeholder handling: Some fields reference specific CA requirements correctly while others remain generic [ORGANIZATION NAME] brackets
The 'welcome script' section contains placeholder text rather than the personalized 60-90 word message from Stephanie Nguyen that should have been generated
Missing the warm, personalized tone requested—reads as a generic template rather than tailored communication from Bayview Health System
Does not demonstrate time-saving value for a large established organization with existing infrastructure
